grammar_notes: Subject pronoun - often omitted when verb conjugation makes subject clear
cultural_note: Portuguese drops pronouns because verb endings already indicate the subject
tip: Practice saying 'Eu sou...' (I am...) to introduce yourself

grammar_notes: Informal 'you' for friends/family - uses 2nd person verb conjugation
cultural_note: In Portugal 'tu' is common casually - some regions prefer 'você' even informally
tip: Use 'tu' only when you're sure the relationship is informal

grammar_notes: Formal 'you' that uses 3rd person verb conjugation (same as ele/ela)
cultural_note: More common in Brazil - in Portugal used for respect or professional settings
tip: When unsure use 'você' - it's safer in professional or new situations

grammar_notes: Masculine 3rd person singular - used for male people and masculine nouns
cultural_note: Portuguese nouns have gender so even objects can be 'ele' if masculine
tip: Remember: ele = he / ela = she - the ending -e vs -a often indicates gender

grammar_notes: Feminine 3rd person singular - used for female people and feminine nouns
cultural_note: Many Portuguese words ending in -a are feminine
tip: Notice how ela ends in -a matching feminine noun patterns

grammar_notes: 1st person plural - accent (ó) indicates stress - informal: 'a gente'
cultural_note: In casual speech 'a gente' is very common as alternative to 'nós'
tip: Informal: 'A gente fala português' = 'Nós falamos português'

grammar_notes: Used for all-male groups OR mixed groups (even 1 male = eles)
cultural_note: Portuguese follows the rule that masculine form is used for mixed groups
tip: Mixed group = masculine plural - standard Portuguese grammar

grammar_notes: Used ONLY for all-female groups - one male switches to 'eles'
cultural_note: Use only when the entire group is female
tip: Remember: elas = all female / eles = any males present or mixed

grammar_notes: Plural 'you' - addressing multiple people - uses 3rd person plural verbs
cultural_note: Used for any group you're addressing directly
tip: Use when talking to more than one person

grammar_notes: Very common informal 'we' - takes 3rd person SINGULAR verb
cultural_note: Extremely common in everyday speech - more casual than 'nós'
tip: A gente + 3rd person singular verb (like ele/ela)
